title: ody language online
intro: The coronavirus pandemic has forced millions of people worldwide to get used to meeting others only through a computer screen. But how can we make these meetings feel more natural? That's what Neil and Sam discuss, as they teach you related vocabulary.
this_week_question: Erica Dhawan may be a communications expert now, but growing up in Pennsylvania she was a shy and quiet schoolgirl. So how did Erica beat her shyness and become the confident communicator she is today? Did she...
b)    copy the body language of the cool kids at school?
c)    raised her hand to answer the teacher’s questions, even if she didn’t know the answer?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: communication though the movements and gestures of your body, rather than with words
two people look at each other’s eyes at the same time
discussing suggestions with a group of people to come up new ideas or solve problems
to understand information by thinking about it and reflecting on it carefully
happening together and at the same time
informal conversations and chats between people in their office or workplace (US)

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I’m Sam. When Neil and I record 6 Minute English face-to-face in the BBC Learning English studio which, I am happy to say, we are doing right now, we look at each other as we speak. We smile and use hand gestures and facial expressions in a type of communication called body language .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But during the Covid pandemic, everyday meetings with work colleagues, teachers and friends, and 6 Minute English recording - all moved online.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Video meetings using software like Zoom and Skype became the normal way to communicate with family and friends. And whatever happens with Covid in the future, it seems they’re here to stay.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In this programme, we’ll be asking: how has body language changed in the world of online video meetings?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: We’ll meet the person who wrote the rulebook for clear communication in the digital age – Erica Dhawan, author of a new book, ‘Digital Body Language’.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But before that, I have a question for you, Sam, and it’s about Erica Dhawan. She may be a communications expert now, but growing up in Pennsylvania she was a shy and quiet schoolgirl. So how did Erica beat her shyness and become the confident communicator she is today? Did she:

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I’ll guess that c – she raised her hand to answer the teacher’s questions.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Sam. We’ll reveal the correct answer later in the programme.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: In face-to-face meetings, we immediately see someone’s reaction to what we’ve said through eye contact , where two people look into each other’s eyes as they talk.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Unfortunately, using a web camera to make eye contact is almost impossible in online meetings and this often creates a kind of ‘distancing’ effect.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Erica Dhawan makes several suggestions to help with this. See if you can hear the final suggestion she makes to Michael Rosen as part of BBC Radio 4’s Word of Mouth.

transcript.author: Erica Dhawan
transcript.text: And last but not least, slow down. Remember when it was completely normal to have a one-minute pause in a room with one another because we knew when we’re thinking and brainstorming . If we don’t hear someone speak on video, we ask them if they’re on mute. Practise what I call the five-second rule – wait five seconds before speaking to make sure that individuals have time to process the ideas, especially if there may be technology or accessibility issues.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Did you hear Erica’s last piece of advice, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, she recommends slowing down, something we do naturally face-to-face when we’re thinking or brainstorming – that’s discussing suggestions with a group of people to come up with new ideas or to solve problems.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Slowing down gives us time to process new information – to understand it by thinking carefully and reflecting on it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Erica compares online body language to learning a new language - it takes practice, especially when it comes to smiling and laughing, something Michael Rosen finds hard to do in video meetings.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Listen to him discussing this problem with Erica Dhawan for BBC Radio 4’s, Word of Mouth.

transcript.author: Michael Rosen
transcript.text: Do you think it’s killing off people laughing and smiling in the way we do when we’re altogether in the live situation?

transcript.author: in unison
transcript.text: I would say that it is much less likely that we laugh and smile on camera for a few reasons. Number one, laughing is often done  where we can quickly pick up the energy of someone smiling or laughing and feed off of that and laugh ourselves. When it comes to screen delays, the fact that it’s not natural to see our own camera – being distracted by that – we are much less likely to laugh and smile. One of the ways we can overcome this is by creating intentional moments in our meetings for the water cooler effect.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Erica points out that laughing often happens in unison – together and at the same time.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, if someone starts laughing it makes me laugh too.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: She also thinks it’s important to make time for employees to chat informally about things unrelated to work – their weekend plans or last night’s TV show.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And she uses the expression, the water cooler effect which comes from the United States where office workers sometimes meet at the water fountain to chat.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: So, the water cooler effect refers to informal conversations that people have in their office or workplace, maybe in the lift, the office kitchen or, if there is one, by an actual water cooler.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Erica Dhawan seems very comfortable communicating online, but she’s had lots of time to practice since her schooldays.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Ah yes, Neil, in your quiz question you asked how Erica conquered her shyness at school. I guessed that she raised her hand to answer the teacher’s questions.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It was a good guess, Sam, but the correct answer is b – she copied the body language of her cool teenage classmates, so probably lots of rolled eyes and slouching!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme about online body language – non-verbal ways of communicating using the body.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Eye contact is when two people look at each other’s eyes at the same time.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Brainstorming involves a group discussion to generate new ideas or solutions.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: When we process information, we think about it carefully in order to understand it.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: In unison means happening together and at the same time

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And finally, the water cooler effect is an American expression to describe informal conversations between people at work.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Neil is looking at his watch, which is body language that tells me our six minutes are up!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye for now!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Goodbye!
